conclusion: Trying to solve an optics problem involving a hemispherical shell and a parallel beam of light.
Hemispherical shell has inner surface radius R and outer surface radius √2R.
Parallel beam of light with cross-sectional radius R is incident on the inner surface.
Task is to determine the radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface where light rays are transmitted.
Hemisphere with inner radius R and outer radius √2R, center at point O, axis of symmetry through O.
A parallel beam of light is coming in parallel to the axis, hitting the inner surface, refracts into the medium, and refracts out at the outer surface.
Consider a single ray from the beam; position within the beam will vary.
Consider the ray that passes through the edge of the inner surface to determine the edge of the illuminated area on the outer surface.
Consider the central ray; it hits the inner surface at the center and refracts straight through.
For the central ray, the point of incidence is along the axis, normal is perpendicular to the axis, and the ray is parallel to the axis.
Inner surface is a hemisphere, normal at the center of the flat side is perpendicular to the flat side, pointing inward towards O.
Hemisphere sitting on its flat side, bottom half of a sphere, center O, inner radius R, outer radius √2R.
Beam is parallel to the axis of symmetry, cross-section radius R, same as inner radius.
Consider the ray that grazes the inner surface at the edge of the beam, at a distance R from the axis.
Normal to the inner surface is along the radius vector from O to the point of incidence.
Angle between the incoming ray and the normal can be found.
Point of incidence on the inner surface is P, angle of incidence determined by distance from the axis.
Cross-section of the hemisphere with O at the center, inner semicircle radius R, outer semicircle radius √2R.
Consider a ray from the beam that hits the inner surface at point P, distance R from the axis.
Normal at P points from O towards P, angle of incidence i is the angle between the incoming ray and the normal at P.
